title: RS22623
content: The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement, survivors, disability, unemployment, and sickness benefits for railroad workers and their families. Workers covered by the RRB system include those employed by railroads engaged in interstate commerce. The RRB system is separate from Social Security but closely coordinated. Insured railroad workers receive RRB annuities instead of Social Security benefits. To be insured for an RRB annuity, a worker must generally have at least 10 years of covered railroad work. Non-railroad workers can receive benefits from RRB or Social Security, depending on their railroad service length. To qualify for an RRB annuity, a worker needs 10 years of covered railroad work or five years post-1995. Family of insured railroad workers get RRB annuities equal to or greater than Social Security benefits. If not eligible for RRB, railroad work counts towards Social Security benefits. RRB annuities have tier I and tier II components, with tier I amounts similar to Social Security benefits. RRB annuities consist of tier I and tier II components. Tier I amounts are like Social Security benefits, calculated based on RRB age and service requirements. Tier II amounts are additional and based solely on covered railroad service. Surviving spouses may be eligible for widow or widower annuities from RRB. Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) annuities include tier I and tier II components, with tier II amounts increasing annually by 32.5% of the Social Security COLA. Surviving spouses of railroad workers may receive higher RRB survivor annuities compared to Social Security benefits, with eligibility for up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity at full retirement age. Widows and widowers can receive a reduced annuity as early as age 60 (or age 50 if disabled), and those caring for a deceased worker's child under age 16 may receive an annuity of up to 75% of the worker's tier I amount plus 100%. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) annuities include tier I and tier II components, with tier II amounts increasing annually by 32.5% of the Social Security COLA. Surviving spouses of railroad workers may receive up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity at full retirement age. Widows and widowers can receive a reduced annuity as early as age 60 (or age 50 if disabled), and those caring for a deceased worker's child under age 16 may receive an annuity of up to 75% of the worker's tier I amount plus 100%. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 increased initial annuities for the widow(er)s of qualifying railroad employees. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for the widow(er)s of qualifying railroad employees and made various other changes to the railroad retirement system, including investment options, early retirement reductions, vesting requirements, annuity limitations, and tax structures. The changes to widow(er)'s annuities apply to all recipients starting in February 2002 or later, with some retroactive adjustments for those who would have received higher benefits under the new law. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for widow(er)s of qualifying railroad employees, with retroactive adjustments for some recipients. The new rules added a guaranty amount to increase initial annuities, setting a supplemental guaranty amount at 50% of the employee's tier II amount. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for widow(er)s of qualifying railroad employees by adding a supplemental guaranty amount, set at 50% of the employee's tier II amount. The total initial minimum amount under current law is 100% of the tier I and tier II amounts the employee would have received, minus any applicable reductions. Both the widow(er)'s tier I amount and regular tier II amount are increased annually. The widow(er)'s annuity increases annually, with tier I amounts rising by the Social Security COLA and regular tier II amounts by 32.5% of the COLA. However, the guaranty amount is reduced by the same dollar amount as the COLA increase, keeping the total annuity constant for several years. Once the guaranty amount reaches zero, the total monthly annuity will start to increase as tier I and regular tier II amounts continue to rise with the COLA. The widow(er)'s annuity will decline in real terms as the guaranty amount is reduced to zero, leading to an increase in total monthly annuity. Under the 2001 law, widow(er)s receive annuities greater than prior law, with average annuity amounts increasing from $1,138 to $1,416 per month in real 2005 dollars. The average aged widow(er) annuity increased from $1,138 to $1,416 per month in real 2005 dollars four years after the change. Widow(er) annuities are calculated differently under current law compared to prior law, resulting in higher initial minimum amounts for widows. The widow's annuity amount increased to $1,300 per month under current law, with $150 more than prior law due to a guaranty amount. Her total annuity will not increase until her tier I and regular tier II amounts exceed the initial minimum amount. The widow's total annuity of $1,300 per month will not increase until her tier I and regular tier II amounts surpass the initial minimum amount. Despite no COLA, her annuity components change yearly, with tier I increasing by $23 and regular tier II by $1 in 2007. The guaranty amount decreases by $24, resulting in a total tier II annuity of $277 in 2007, higher than under prior law. The widow's guaranty amount decreases by $24, from $150 to $126, due to an annual offset. Her total tier II annuity under current law would be $277 in 2007, higher than under prior law. Starting in 2012, her total monthly annuity would increase due to COLAs, reaching $1,323, higher than her 2011 amount of $1,300. Starting in 2012, the widow's total monthly annuity would exceed her initial minimum amount, reaching $1,323, higher than her 2011 amount of $1,300. The differences between current and prior law are shown in Figure 1, with the widow receiving a guaranty amount under current law, bringing her total annuity to $1,300 in 2006. Under prior law, the widow's monthly annuity in 2006 would have been $1,150, consisting of tier I and tier II amounts. However, under current law, the widow also receives a guaranty amount, bringing her total annuity in 2006 to $1,300. The guaranty amount decreases each year after 2006 as tier I and tier II amounts increase.
